newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-New method doesn't affect Australia jobs - ABS.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-New method doesn't affect Australia jobs - ABS.

text.p: The introduction of telephone interviewing had no noticeable impact on the Australian employment rate so far, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) said in a statement on Wednesday.
"At this point in time, after the four-month period August to November 1996, no noticeable effect on the employment rate for each of the months has been detected," the (ABS) said.
Sources familiar with the data have said that the ABS had noticed an effect on the unemployment rate from the progressive replacement of the face-to-face technique with telephone interviewing.
A spokesman for the bureau declined to quantify the difference in unemployment rates detected by the two methods during the phase-in period.
"We're not commenting beyond the statement," he told Reuters.

The statement also said: "The ABS will continue to closely monitor the key labour force series for any significant effects as the phase-in continues. If, and when, any noticeable effect is detected the ABS will report it in the monthly publication Labour Force, Australia."
Other countries, such as Canada, Britain and the United States, had introduced telephone interviewing without detrimentally affecting the key labour data, the bureau said.
"Telephone interviewing can deliver productivity improvements without loss of data quality and timeliness."
The sample in the bureau's monthly population survey, which produces the labour statistics, is divided into eight panels each of about 8,000 people. Each month the bureau replaces a panel.
Since August, every new panel has been a telephone panel as the bureau phases in the new method.
The sources told Reuters that telephone interviewing produced an unemployment rate about half a percentage point higher than the old method in the first few months of the phase-in.
After the latest data was included, the difference was lower but still positive, they said.
The bureau has not conducted a parallel study of the two methods and is relying on the phase-in period to detect any effect.
No-one has suggested that the new method is less accurate. Rather, the issue has been any distortion in the rate of change of the unemployment rate during the phase-in.

The Australian Statistician, Bill McLennan, said in a speech in July that overseas experience suggested a small but probably insignificant positive effect on the unemployment rate from telephone interviewing.
